abstract.p: Indiana University researchers find being kind at work, and a team player, boosts career advancement and corporate performance (M)

block.p: December can be a pleasant month at work, with people seemingly cheery, and some, well, even nice.
The skeptic in you may think that the situation will change come January, after the holidays. But that might not be the case if you, your co-workers and your company hope to get ahead.
December can be a pleasant month at work, with people seemingly cheery, and some, well, even nice.
The skeptic in you may think that the situation will change come January, after the holidays. But that might not be the case if you, your co-workers and your company hope to get ahead.
Two researchers from Indiana University's Kelley School of Business have found that being kind at work, and a team player, pays dividends in career advancement and corporate performance.
''For the vast majority of people, what we've proven is that nice people don't finish last -- far from it,'' said one of the researchers, Scott B. MacKenzie, a marketing professor.

Since 1989, Professor MacKenzie and Philip M. Podsakoff, professor of management, have studied how the careers of thousands of employees -- from insurance sales representatives to store clerks to executives -- have been affected by their workplace behavior. In a 1996 study, for example, they found that 26 percent of the variation in the quantity of paper produced by mill work crews was tied to good behavior.

Engaging in good ''organizational citizenship behavior,'' the researchers found, is just as important as an employee's performance numbers. They also found that companies populated with nice people tended to generate better bottom lines.
Most workers are about average in skills and performance, Professor MacKenzie says. ''That's where individual citizenship efforts make the biggest difference'' in raises, promotions and careers.
Even so, the researchers note, a stellar performer who is not so kind can still rise to the top. Likewise, they say, being nice only gets you so far; you still have to produce results.
The researchers listed attributes that they deemed vital to success -- and an example of each:
* Altruism. Helping colleagues with work-related problems.
* Courtesy. Keeping co-workers abreast of what you are doing.
* Civic virtue. Being willing to say what you think is in the best interest of the company, even if it may not be popular.
* Sportsmanship. Being a good sport, and not complaining all the time.
Finally, a study last year found that the higher the rank, the more that executives appeared to be behaving in kind ways.
''It's the way to get ahead,'' Professor MacKenzie said.
